TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
   - A line placed, measuring BP higher than cuff
   - lisinopril restarted, but pt not given b/c of high likelihood of
   intubation
   - TTE Monday
   - conversation w daughter prior to intubation
   - ESR, thyroid function tests; ddx includes papillary thyroid
   carcinoma, viral pneumonias, vasculitides
   - Pm lytes showed persistent hypernatremia, mildly improved
   (148-->147)-- didnt get free water in setting of tenuous respiratory
   status on bipap
   - DNR but OK to intubate if thought to be temporary
   - OSH cultures NGTD ; need to redo sputum cultures here - induced
   - ESR 93 ; PM Creat bumped from 1.8 --> 2.3
   - intubated 20:30 for worsening hypoxia and confusion on Bipap -- right
   mainstem intubation, was desatting, and ETT pulled back slightly by RT
   before first CXR ; First CXR confirmed ETT was just past carina on R--
   changes seen in R lung b/c hypoventilated; ETT pulled back to 20cm (was
   originally at 25cm), and CXR re-taken w ETT ~3cm from carina
   - at time of intubation, pt given 1.3L NS for hypotension from
   sedation; hypotension resolved quickly
   - NG tube placed
   - ventilate at 6cc/kg ; on 100% fiO2
   - after ETT pulled back second time (to 20cm), pt was given extra
   sedation, and BPs dropped to 80s (MAP 50), so sedation decreased, and
   he was bolused 500cc NS, responded well
   - ESR 93 ; Anti-GBM and ANCA pending
   - 5:20am BPs dropping again to 80s systolic (mid 50s MAP)--> 200cc NS
   bolus and dropped sedation further
   Allergies:
   Darvon (Oral) (Propoxyphene Hcl)
   Confusion/Delir
   Tramadol

   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:12.9/29.4/1.1, ALT / AST:39/28, Alk Phos / T
   Bili:84/0.8, Differential-Neuts:94.8 %, Lymph:3.0 %, Mono:2.0 %,
   Eos:0.1 %, Lactic Acid:1.5 mmol/L, Albumin:2.8 g/dL, LDH:466 IU/L,
   Ca++:7.9 mg/dL, Mg++:2.1 mg/dL, PO4:3.5 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   85yo M with h/o HTN, CRI, anxiety, and recent admission at OSH for
   gastroenteritis, who is transfered from an OSH with worsening acute
   hypoxic respiratory failure and PNA.
   .
   # Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: Patient likely hypoxic secondary to PNA
   from aspiration per OSH records. Given progression, concern exists for
   possible [**Doctor Last Name 11**]/ARDS. His hypoxia is presently refractory to 70% FiO2,
   likely related to a shunt (?intracardiac vs airspace disease preventing
   sufficient recruitment). Further workup for causes of hypoxia (eg PE)
   limited given CRI so unable to obtain CTA. Some mention of improvement
   with diuresis today but no record re: LV function. Patient noted to
   desat on exam when laying flat with resolution when sitting up,
   concerning for CHF exacerbation. However was hypotensive after
   diuresis, without any improvement in saturation. Patient had received
   steroids at OSH. Given that unlikely COPD exacerbation given no prior
   history of COPD and lack of wheezing on exam, will not continue
   steroids.
   - TTE with bubble study in am
   - manipulate vent settings
     - want to make patient more passive .
     - increase PEEP, aware that it can drop preload and possibly
   necessitate pressor initiation.
     - consider ARDS and restricting tidal volume to 4-6 cc/kg.
   - Considering Chest CT if stable and no other diagnostic clues
   - Continue broad spectrum abx with Vanc/Zosyn/cipro for now.
   - Endotracheal sputum cultures, blood cultures.
   - Follow up cultures from OSH inc legionella, mycoplasma.
   - Could consider V/Q scan if high suspicion for PE (currently with PNA
   this is less likely so will hold for now).
   - Keep net even for now given h/o CRI.
   .
   # Hypotension
   - Volume expansion with 1/2NS to avoid worsening hypernatremia
   - Holding lisinopril, will hold doxazosin.
   .
   # Hypernatremia
 persistent, with hyperchloremia
   - free water flushes, 150 cc q4
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Pt had leukocytosis on admission to OSH of 14. This has
   bumped to 27.9 at time of transfer.  Could represent progression of
   infection/PNA, but more likely a result of IV steroids given at OSH.
   - Trend WBC.
   - D/ced steroids as not indicated since presentation not c/w COPD
   exacerbation.
   .
   # Chronic Renal Insufficiency: Baseline creatinine of 2 per OSH records
   and currently 2.3, from 1.9 at OSH at time of transfer.
   - Trend BUN/Cr.
   - Renally dose meds.
   - Avoid nephrotoxins.
   - Monitor UOP.
   .
   # Aspiration: this is likely the source of his PNA based on OSH records
   and failed limited S+S eval at OSH when on bipap.
   - Tube feeds with nutrition recs
   - Treating aspiration PNA with abx as above.
   - When extubated will need S+S eval prior to eating.
   - HOB elevation, aspiration precautions.
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: Continue current regimen of pravastatin 10 mg QHS.
   .
   #  FEN: IVF bolus PRN for low UOP, replete electrolytes PRN, NPO.
   .
   # Access: PICC to be placed today
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2112-3-6**] 05:46 AM
   Arterial Line - [**2112-3-6**] 01:29 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: HSQ
   Stress ulcer: famotidine
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: DNR (okay for intubation for now)
   Disposition:

Summary:

The patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of hypertension, chronic renal insufficiency, anxiety, and recent admission to the hospital for gastroenteritis. He was transferred from an outside hospital with worsening acute hypoxic respiratory failure and pneumonia (PNA). He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with 70% FiO2. His hypoxia is refractory and likely related to a shunt, possibly intracardiac or airspace disease. He has a history of chronic renal insufficiency and is receiving diuretics, which may have contributed to his hypotension. He also has hypernatremia, leukocytosis, and hyperlipidemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): Given the patient's refractory hypoxia and possible shunt, there is a concern for ARDS.
2. Pneumonia (PNA): The patient has a history of aspiration and failed limited swallowing evaluation at the outside hospital, which may have contributed to his PNA.
3. Chronic Renal Insufficiency (CRI): The patient's baseline creatinine is 2, and his current creatinine is 2.3, indicating worsening renal function.
4. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be related to diuretics, CRI, and possible sepsis.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia is persistent, with hyperchloremia, and may require further management to avoid worsening electrolyte imbalances.
6. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may be related to IV steroids given at the outside hospital or progression of infection/PNA.
7. Aspiration: The patient's aspiration is likely the source of his PNA, and he will require tube feeds and aspiration precautions when extubated.
8. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia is being managed with pravastatin, but further monitoring is necessary to ensure adequate control.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's hypoxic respiratory failure is refractory, and further workup is necessary to determine the cause. A TTE with bubble study is planned to assess for possible cardiac shunt. The patient's hypotension is being managed with volume expansion and diuretics, and his hypernatremia is being treated with free water flushes. His leukocytosis is being trended, and his CRI is being monitored. The patient's aspiration is being treated with tube feeds and aspiration precautions, and his hyperlipidemia is being managed with pravastatin.

   Assessment and Plan
   85yo M with h/o HTN, CRI, anxiety, and recent admission at OSH for
   gastroenteritis, who is transfered from an OSH with worsening acute
   hypoxic respiratory failure and PNA.
   .
   # Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: Patient likely hypoxic secondary to PNA
   from aspiration per OSH records. Given progression, concern exists for
   possible [**Doctor Last Name 11**]/ARDS. His hypoxia is presently refractory to 70% FiO2,
   likely related to a shunt (?intracardiac vs airspace disease preventing
   sufficient recruitment). Further workup for causes of hypoxia (eg PE)
   limited given CRI so unable to obtain CTA. Some mention of improvement
   with diuresis today but no record re: LV function. Patient noted to
   desat on exam when laying flat with resolution when sitting up,
   concerning for CHF exacerbation. However was hypotensive after
   diuresis, without any improvement in saturation. Patient had received
   steroids at OSH. Given that unlikely COPD exacerbation given no prior
   history of COPD and lack of wheezing on exam, will not continue
   steroids.
   - TTE with bubble study in am
   - manipulate vent settings
     - want to make patient more passive .
     - increase PEEP, aware that it can drop preload and possibly
   necessitate pressor initiation.
     - consider ARDS and restricting tidal volume to 4-6 cc/kg.
   - Considering Chest CT if stable and no other diagnostic clues
   - Continue broad spectrum abx with Vanc/Zosyn/cipro for now.
   - Endotracheal sputum cultures, blood cultures.
   - Follow up cultures from OSH inc legionella, mycoplasma.
   - Could consider V/Q scan if high suspicion for PE (currently with PNA
   this is less likely so will hold for now).
   - Keep net even for now given h/o CRI.
   - Check BNP, was 228 at OSH on [**3-5**].
   .
   # Hypotension
   - Volume expansion with 1/2NS to avoid worsening hypernatremia
   .
   # Hypernatremia
 persistent, with hyperchloremia
   - free water flushes, 150 cc q4
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Pt had leukocytosis on admission to OSH of 14. This has
   bumped to 27.9 at time of transfer.  Could represent progression of
   infection/PNA, but more likely a result of IV steroids given at OSH.
   - Trend WBC.
   - D/c steroids as not indicated since presentation not c/w COPD
   exacerbation.
   .
   # Chronic Renal Insufficiency: Baseline creatinine of 2 per OSH records
   and currently 2.3, from 1.9 at OSH at time of transfer.
   - Trend BUN/Cr.
   - Renally dose meds.
   - Avoid nephrotoxins.
   - Monitor UOP.
   .
   # Aspiration: this is likely the source of his PNA based on OSH records
   and failed limited S+S eval at OSH when on bipap.
   - Tube feeds with nutrition recs
   - Treating aspiration PNA with abx as above.
   - When extubated will need S+S eval prior to eating.
   - HOB elevation, aspiration precautions.
   .
   # HTN: Currently patient's BP is 148/74.  At home patient is on
   lisinopril. Repeat creatinine here 1.8. Since he is at his baseline
   creatinine, will continue his current regimen of lisinopril 10 mg daily
   starting in AM.
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: Continue current regimen of pravastatin 10 mg QHS.
   .
   #  FEN: IVF bolus PRN for low UOP, replete electrolytes PRN, NPO.
   .
   # Access: PICC to be placed today
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:

   DVT: HSQ
   Stress ulcer: famotidine

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 85-year-old male with a history of hypertension, chronic renal insufficiency, anxiety, and recent admission for gastroenteritis. He was transferred to the ICU with worsening acute hypoxic respiratory failure and pneumonia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: Intubated and ventilated at 6cc/kg with 100% FiO2, showing signs of hypoxia and worsening acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
* Cardiovascular: Hypotensive, with blood pressure dropping to 80s systolic (mid 50s MAP) after sedation, but responding well to boluses of normal saline.
* Neurological: Minimally responsive, with confusion and delirium.
* Renal: Chronic renal insufficiency, with a baseline creatinine of 2 and currently 2.3.
* Laboratory results:
	+ WBC: 27.9
	+ Hct: 32.8
	+ Plt: 228
	+ Cr: 2.3
	+ TCO2: 24
	+ Glucose: 107
	+ Lactic acid: 1.5 mmol/L
	+ Albumin: 2.8 g/dL
	+ LDH: 466 IU/L
	+ Ca++: 7.9 mg/dL
	+ Mg++: 2.1 mg/dL
	+ PO4: 3.5 mg/dL

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Further worsening of ARDS, leading to respiratory failure
* Development of sepsis or septic shock
* Progression of chronic renal insufficiency to acute kidney injury
* Hypotension and decreased cardiac output
* Increased risk of respiratory infections, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
* Potential for aspiration pneumonia to worsen
* Hypernatremia and hyperchloremia, leading to electrolyte imbalances
* Increased risk of bleeding due to coagulopathy
* Potential for cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest due to hypoxia and electrolyte imbalances

The patient's plan of care includes:

* TTE with bubble study in the morning to assess for cardiac function and potential intracardiac shunting
* Manipulation of ventilator settings to optimize oxygenation and reduce risk of ARDS
* Consideration of chest CT scan if the patient is stable and no other diagnostic clues are available
* Continued broad-spectrum antibiotics for pneumonia
* Endotracheal sputum cultures, blood cultures, and follow-up cultures from OSH for legionella and mycoplasma
* Monitoring of blood pressure, electrolytes, and renal function
* Avoidance of nephrotoxins and monitoring of urine output
* Tube feeds with nutrition recommendations
* Treatment of aspiration pneumonia with antibiotics
* HOB elevation and aspiration precautions when extubated
* Repeat creatinine and electrolyte monitoring to assess for potential changes in renal function and electrolyte imbalances.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has worsening acute hypoxic respiratory failure, which can lead to respiratory arrest if not managed promptly.
2. Pneumonia (PNA): The patient has a high likelihood of PNA due to aspiration, which can lead to sepsis, multi-organ failure, and increased mortality.
3. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient has chronic renal insufficiency, and the high doses of IV lasix and other nephrotoxic medications can exacerbate kidney damage.
4. Hyperkalemia: The patient has hypernatremia and mildly improved electrolyte levels, which can lead to hyperkalemia, especially with the use of IV lasix and other medications.
5. Hypotension: The patient has had episodes of hypotension, which can be life-threatening, especially in the setting of respiratory failure and PNA.
6. Sedation-related complications: The patient has been receiving sedation for respiratory support, which can lead to respiratory depression, hypotension, and other complications.
7. Infection: The patient has a high risk of developing secondary infections, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), due to the presence of an endotracheal tube and the use of antibiotics.
8. Cardiovascular complications: The patient has a history of chronic renal insufficiency, hypertension, and possible CHF exacerbation, which can lead to cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, and cardiac arrest.
9. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of gastroenteritis and aspiration, which can lead to gastrointestinal bleeding, perforation, and other complications.
10. Neurological complications: The patient has a high risk of developing neurological complications, such as seizures, cerebral edema, and brain herniation, due to the presence of PNA, hypoxia, and other systemic complications.

Based on the patient's medical history and current condition, it is essential to closely monitor his respiratory, cardiac, renal, and neurological status, as well as to manage his infection, sedation, and electrolyte levels to prevent these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   85yo M with h/o HTN, CRI, anxiety, and recent admission at OSH for
   gastroenteritis, who is transfered from an OSH with worsening acute
   hypoxic respiratory failure and PNA.
   .
   # Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: Patient likely hypoxic secondary to PNA
   from aspiration per OSH records. Given progression, concern exists for
   possible [**Doctor Last Name 11**]/ARDS. His hypoxia is presently refractory to 70% FiO2,
   likely related to a shunt (?intracardiac vs airspace disease preventing
   sufficient recruitment). Further workup for causes of hypoxia (eg PE)
   limited given CRI so unable to obtain CTA. Some mention of improvement
   with diuresis today but no record re: LV function. Patient noted to
   desat on exam when laying flat with resolution when sitting up,
   concerning for CHF exacerbation. However was hypotensive after
   diuresis, without any improvement in saturation. Patient had received
   steroids at OSH. Given that unlikely COPD exacerbation given no prior
   history of COPD and lack of wheezing on exam, will not continue
   steroids.
   - TTE with bubble study in am
   - manipulate vent settings
     - want to make patient more passive .
     - increase PEEP, aware that it can drop preload and possibly
   necessitate pressor initiation.
     - consider ARDS and restricting tidal volume to 4-6 cc/kg.
   - Considering Chest CT if stable and no other diagnostic clues
   - Continue broad spectrum abx with Vanc/Zosyn/cipro for now.
   - Endotracheal sputum cultures, blood cultures.
   - Follow up cultures from OSH inc legionella, mycoplasma.
   - Could consider V/Q scan if high suspicion for PE (currently with PNA
   this is less likely so will hold for now).
   - Keep net even for now given h/o CRI.
   - Check BNP, was 228 at OSH on [**3-5**].
   .
   # Hypotension
   - Volume expansion with 1/2NS to avoid making acidotic
   .
   # Hypernatremia
 new, with hyperchloremic
   - free water flushes, 150 cc q4
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Pt had leukocytosis on admission to OSH of 14. This has
   bumped to 27.9 at time of transfer.  Could represent progression of
   infection/PNA, but more likely a result of IV steroids given at OSH.
   - Trend WBC.
   - D/c steroids as not indicated since presentation not c/w COPD
   exacerbation.
   .
   # Chronic Renal Insufficiency: Baseline creatinine of 2 per OSH records
   and currently 2.3, from 1.9 at OSH at time of transfer.
   - Trend BUN/Cr.
   - Renally dose meds.
   - Avoid nephrotoxins.
   - Monitor UOP.
   .
   # Aspiration: this is likely the source of his PNA based on OSH records
   and failed limited S+S eval at OSH when on bipap.
   - Tube feeds with nutrition recs
   - Treating aspiration PNA with abx as above.
   - When extubated will need S+S eval prior to eating.
   - HOB elevation, aspiration precautions..
   .
   # HTN: Currently patient's BP is 148/74.  At home patient is on
   lisinopril. Repeat creatinine here 1.8. Since he is at his baseline
   creatinine, will continue his current regimen of lisinopril 10 mg daily
   starting in AM.
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: Continue current regimen of pravastatin 10 mg QHS.
   .
   #  FEN: IVF bolus PRN for low UOP, replete electrolytes PRN, NPO.

Summary:

The patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of hypertension, chronic renal insufficiency, anxiety, and recent admission for gastroenteritis. He was transferred from an outside hospital (OSH) with worsening acute hypoxic respiratory failure and pneumonia (PNA). He was intubated due to worsening hypoxia and confusion on bipap. The patient has a high likelihood of aspiration, and his PNA is likely secondary to aspiration. He has hypernatremia, leukocytosis, and chronic renal insufficiency. He is also hypertensive and has hyperlipidemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to aspiration, and he may require continued mechanical ventilation and possible consideration of ARDS.
2. Pneumonia: The patient has a high likelihood of aspiration, and his PNA is likely secondary to aspiration. He may require continued antibiotic treatment and consideration of additional diagnostic tests, such as a chest CT.
3. Hypernatremia: The patient has hypernatremia, which may require treatment with free water flushes and close monitoring of his electrolyte levels.
4. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may be due to progression of infection or IV steroids given at OSH. Close monitoring of his WBC count and consideration of steroid therapy are necessary.
5. Chronic Renal Insufficiency: The patient has chronic renal insufficiency, which may require close monitoring of his creatinine levels, renally dosed medications, and avoidance of nephrotoxins.
6. Hypertension: The patient has hypertension, which may require continued treatment with lisinopril and close monitoring of his blood pressure.
7. Hyperlipidemia: The patient has hyperlipidemia, which may require continued treatment with pravastatin and close monitoring of his lipid levels.
8. Aspiration: The patient has a high likelihood of aspiration, which may require close monitoring of his airway and consideration of aspiration precautions.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is complex, and close monitoring is necessary to prevent potential complications. The plan includes continued mechanical ventilation, antibiotic treatment, and consideration of additional diagnostic tests. The patient's electrolyte levels, WBC count, and creatinine levels will need to be closely monitored. He will also require close monitoring of his airway and consideration of aspiration precautions.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of hypertension, chronic renal insufficiency, anxiety, and recent admission for gastroenteritis, who was transferred to the ICU due to worsening acute hypoxic respiratory failure and pneumonia.

The patient's current condition is concerning for:

1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient's hypoxia is refractory to 70% FiO2, and further workup for causes of hypoxia is limited due to chronic renal insufficiency. The CXR suggests TB, and the patient is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics.
2. Hypotension: The patient became acutely hypotensive overnight and required three pressors (levo, neo, and vaso) initially, now weaned down to two (levo and vaso). The likely cause is sepsis, and treating the underlying infection is expected to improve this.
3. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia has resolved, and free water flushes are being continued.
4. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis is likely due to IV steroids given at OSH and is now trending down.
5. Chronic Renal Insufficiency: The patient's creatinine level has increased from 1.9 to 2.6, likely due to poor forward flow due to hypotension.
6. Aspiration: The patient likely aspirated during the admission, leading to pneumonia, and tube feeds with nutrition recommendations are being continued.
7. Fever: The patient has a fever, and the cause is unknown.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxia is refractory, and further deterioration is possible.
2. Sepsis: The patient's hypotension and leukocytosis are concerning for sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's chronic renal insufficiency may worsen due to hypotension and sepsis.
4. Pneumonia: The patient's aspiration pneumonia may progress, leading to further respiratory compromise.
5. Tuberculosis: The patient's CXR suggests TB, and further workup is necessary to confirm the diagnosis.
6. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia may worsen due to the underlying medical conditions.

The patient requires close monitoring and management of his respiratory, cardiac, and renal status. Further workup is necessary to confirm the diagnosis of TB and to rule out other causes of hypoxia. The patient's antibiotic regimen should be continued, and consideration should be given to empiric treatment for TB.

   depended on 3 pressors(levo/neo/vaso) initially, now weaned down to 2
   (levo/vaso).  Likely [**1-12**] sepsis, treating the underlying infection will
   improve this.
   - volume expansion with NS
   - wean sedation as tolerated
   - Holding lisinopril, will hold doxazosin.
   # Hypernatremia
 persistent, with hyperchloremia, now resolved.
   - free water flushes, 150 cc q4
   # Leukocytosis: Pt had leukocytosis on admission to OSH of 14. This has
   bumped to 27.9 at time of transfer.  Could represent progression of
   infection/PNA, but more likely a result of IV steroids given at OSH.
   Now down trending
   - Trend WBC
   - D/C
ed steroids as it was felt that his presentation was not c/w COPD
   exacerbation.
   - If hypersensitivity pneumonitis is thought to be a possible source,
   could reinitiate steroid therapy.  Will discuss with chest radiology if
   appearance on CXR could be consistent.
   # Chronic Renal Insufficiency: Baseline creatinine of 2 per OSH records
   and currently 2.6, from 1.9 at OSH at time of transfer.  Likely due to
   poor forward flow due to hypotension (likely severe sepsis).
   - Trend BUN/Cr.
   - Renally dose meds.
   - Avoid nephrotoxins.
   - Monitor UOP.
   # Aspiration: this is likely the source of his PNA based on OSH records
   and failed limited S+S eval at OSH when on bipap.
   - Tube feeds with nutrition recs

   - When extubated will need S+S eval prior to eating.
   - HOB elevation, aspiration precautions.

Summary:

The patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of hypertension, chronic renal insufficiency, and anxiety, who was admitted to the ICU with worsening acute hypoxic respiratory failure and pneumonia (PNA). He has been transferred from an outside hospital with a diagnosis of gastroenteritis. The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 70%. He has been treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics, including vancomycin, piperacillin-tazobactam, and ciprofloxacin.

The patient's condition is complicated by several factors, including hypotension, hypernatremia, leukocytosis, and chronic renal insufficiency. He has a history of chronic renal insufficiency and is currently on dialysis. His blood pressure is unstable, and he has required multiple pressors to maintain adequate blood pressure. He has also developed hypernatremia, which is being treated with free water flushes.

The patient's respiratory status is concerning, with worsening hypoxia and hypercapnia. He has a high risk of developing acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and is being treated with a combination of mechanical ventilation and non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV).

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's hypotension, tachycardia, and leukocytosis are consistent with sepsis. He has been treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics, but the source of his infection is still unknown.
2. ARDS: The patient's hypoxia and hypercapnia are concerning for ARDS. He has been treated with mechanical ventilation and NIPPV, but his oxygenation remains poor.
3. Chronic Renal Insufficiency: The patient's chronic renal insufficiency is being exacerbated by his hypotension and sepsis. He is at risk for acute kidney injury (AKI) and may require dialysis.
4. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is a concern, as it may be a sign of sepsis or cardiogenic shock. He has been treated with multiple pressors, but his blood pressure remains unstable.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia is being treated with free water flushes, but it may be a sign of underlying electrolyte imbalances.
6. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis is concerning, as it may be a sign of infection or inflammation. He has been treated with antibiotics, but the source of his infection is still unknown.
7. Fungal Infection: The patient's respiratory isolation and treatment with antifungal medications suggest that fungal infection is a possibility. Further testing is needed to confirm this diagnosis.
8. Tuberculosis: The patient's chest X-ray suggests that tuberculosis may be a possibility. Further testing is needed to confirm this diagnosis.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and treatment. He is at risk for several medical complications, including sepsis, ARDS, chronic renal insufficiency, hypotension, hypernatremia, leukocytosis, fungal infection, and tuberculosis.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications and potential issues can arise:

1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient's hypoxia is refractory to 70% FiO2, and further workup for causes of hypoxia is limited due to chronic renal insufficiency (CRI). The patient's desaturation on exam when laying flat and resolution when sitting up suggests possible chronic heart failure (CHF) exacerbation. However, the patient's hypotension after diuresis and lack of improvement in saturation suggest that the hypoxia may be due to severe V/Q mismatch.
2. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient's CXR suggests TB, and the patient's hypoxia may have a component of ARDS. The patient's respiratory acidosis and worsening hypotension suggest that the patient may be developing ARDS.
3. Sepsis: The patient's hypotension and leukocytosis suggest that the patient may be developing sepsis. The patient's underlying infection, likely aspiration pneumonia, is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics.
4. Chronic Renal Insufficiency (CRI): The patient's baseline creatinine is 2, and the patient's creatinine has increased to 2.6, suggesting worsening renal function. The patient's hypotension and poor forward flow due to sepsis may be contributing to the worsening renal function.
5. Aspiration: The patient's aspiration pneumonia is likely due to the patient's gastroenteritis and may be contributing to the patient's hypoxia and sepsis.
6. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia is being treated with pravastatin, but the patient's recent admission for gastroenteritis may have exacerbated the condition.
7. Fever: The patient's fever is likely due to the patient's underlying infection and may be contributing to the patient's hypotension and worsening renal function.
8. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely due to sepsis and may be contributing to the patient's worsening renal function and hypoxia.
9. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis is likely due to the patient's underlying infection and may be contributing to the patient's hypoxia and sepsis.
10. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia is likely due to the patient's underlying infection and may be contributing to the patient's hypotension and worsening renal function.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following plan of care is recommended:

1. Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics to treat the patient's underlying infection.
2. Manipulate ventilator settings to maintain the patient's oxygen saturation.
3. Consider ARDS and restricting tidal volume to 4-6 cc/kg.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust medications accordingly.
5. Consider empiric treatment for TB based on the patient's CXR.
6. Follow up fungal markers to consider fungal infection.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust medications accordingly.
8. Consider V/Q scan if high suspicion for PE.
9. Consider Chest CT if stable and no other diagnostic clues.
10. Keep the patient's net even for now given the patient's h/o CRI.

The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate), and the patient's disposition is unclear.

Summary:

The patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of hypertension, chronic renal insufficiency, anxiety, and recent admission for gastroenteritis, who was transferred to the ICU due to worsening acute hypoxic respiratory failure and pneumonia (PNA). He has a history of COPD exacerbation and was given steroids at the outside hospital, which were later held. The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 70%. He has developed hypotension, which is being treated with vasopressors, and has hypernatremia, which is being managed with free water flushes.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient's worsening hypoxic respiratory failure and PNA increase the risk of ARDS, which could lead to further respiratory failure and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Sepsis: The patient's hypotension and leukocytosis suggest the possibility of sepsis, which could worsen his condition and lead to organ failure.
3. Chronic Renal Insufficiency: The patient's baseline creatinine of 2 and current creatinine of 2.6 indicate chronic renal insufficiency, which could worsen with further kidney damage from hypotension and sepsis.
4. Aspiration: The patient's history of aspiration and PNA increase the risk of further aspiration events, which could lead to respiratory failure and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia could worsen his condition and increase the risk of cardiovascular complications.
6. Fever: The patient's fever could be a sign of infection, which could worsen his condition and lead to further complications.
7. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension could worsen his condition and lead to organ failure, particularly if not treated promptly and effectively.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient requires continued mechanical ventilation, vasopressors, and antibiotics to manage his respiratory failure, hypotension, and PNA. He also requires close monitoring of his renal function and electrolyte levels to prevent further complications. Further diagnostic tests, such as a chest CT, may be necessary to determine the cause of his PNA and ARDS. The patient's hyperlipidemia should be managed with current medication regimen.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 70-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), chronic renal failure, and hypotension. The patient's condition has been unstable, with ongoing respiratory distress and hypotension requiring vasopressor support.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated inflammatory markers, including white blood cell count, C-reactive protein, and lactate dehydrogenase. The patient's renal function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 2.4 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen level of 27 mg/dL.

The patient's respiratory status has been managed with mechanical ventilation, with a tidal volume of 400 mL and a respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute. The patient's oxygen saturation has been maintained at 100% with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 70%.

The patient's medication regimen includes vasopressin, norepinephrine, and midazolam, which have been titrated to maintain adequate blood pressure and sedation. The patient has also received antibiotics, including piperacillin-tazobactam and vancomycin, for suspected sepsis.

The patient's fungal markers are pending, and the patient is being treated for possible hypersensitivity pneumonitis. The patient's urine legionella/histo and Hanta virus tests are pending, and the patient has received one dose of gentamycin.

The patient's condition is considered unstable, and the medical team is monitoring the patient closely for signs of worsening respiratory distress, hypotension, or sepsis. The patient's code status is do not resuscitate (DNR), and the patient's disposition is currently unknown.

Potential medical complications that may arise in this patient include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS may progress to respiratory failure, requiring further mechanical ventilation and possible extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
2. Sepsis: The patient's suspected sepsis may worsen, leading to organ dysfunction and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. Renal failure: The patient's chronic renal failure may worsen, requiring further dialysis and potentially impacting the patient's overall prognosis.
4. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may worsen, requiring further vasopressor support and potentially impacting the patient's cardiac output.
5. Fungal infections: The patient's fungal markers are pending, and the patient is being treated for possible hypersensitivity pneumonitis. Fungal infections may worsen, leading to potentially life-threatening complications.

In conclusion, the patient is a high-risk individual with multiple comorbidities and a complex medical condition. The patient's condition is considered unstable, and the medical team is monitoring the patient closely for signs of worsening respiratory distress, hypotension, or sepsis. Further monitoring and management are necessary to prevent potential medical complications and improve the patient's overall prognosis.

   Assessment and Plan
   85yo M with h/o HTN, CRI, anxiety, and recent admission at OSH for
   gastroenteritis, who is transfered from an OSH with worsening acute
   hypoxic respiratory failure and PNA.
   .
   # Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: Patient likely hypoxic secondary to PNA
   from aspiration per OSH records. Given progression, concern exists for
   possible [**Doctor Last Name 11**]/ARDS.  Hypoxia was refractory to 70% FiO2, question if
   shunt (?intracardiac vs airspace disease preventing sufficient
   recruitment). Further workup for causes of hypoxia (eg PE) limited
   given CRI so unable to obtain CTA. Some mention of improvement with
   diuresis today but no record re: LV function. Patient noted to desat on
   exam when laying flat with resolution when sitting up, concerning for
   CHF exacerbation. However was hypotensive after diuresis, without any
   improvement in saturation. Patient had received steroids at OSH. Given
   that unlikely COPD exacerbation given no prior history of COPD and lack
   of wheezing on exam, will not continue steroids.  TEE was performed and
   no intracardiac shunt was identified.  Hypoxemia is likely [**1-12**] severe
   V/Q mismatch (with V/Q close to 0
 ie. Intrapulmonary shunt)
 though
   he was somewhat responsive to O2.  [**Month (only) 51**] have a component of ARDS in this
   picture.   CXR suggested TB.
   - as patient
s pressures worsened yesterday and oxygenation remained
   constant, decrease PEEP to improve preload
   - restricted tidal volume as per ARDS protocol
   - Continue broad spectrum abx with Vanc/Zosyn/cipro for now.
   - Endotracheal sputum cultures, blood cultures.
   - respiratory isolation for r/o TB
 get 3x induced sputum or get BAL
   sample, consider empiric treatment.
   - follow up fungal markers
 for consideration of  fungal infection
   - ID consult
 is empiric treatment for TB indicated?  Anti-fungal
   coverage?  Any other workup indicated?
   - Follow up cultures from OSH inc legionella, mycoplasma.
   - Considering Chest CT if stable and no other diagnostic clues
   - Keep net even for now given h/o CRI.
   # Hypotension: patient became acutely hypotensive o/n on [**3-7**], was
   depended on 3 pressors(levo/neo/vaso) initially, now weaned down to 2
   (levo/vaso).  Likely [**1-12**] sepsis, treating the underlying infection will
   improve this.
   - volume expansion with NS
   - wean sedation as tolerated
   - Holding lisinopril, will hold doxazosin.
   # Hypernatremia
 persistent, with hyperchloremia, now resolved.
   - free water flushes, 150 cc q4
   # Leukocytosis: Pt had leukocytosis on admission to OSH of 14. This has
   bumped to 27.9 at time of transfer.  Could represent progression of
   infection/PNA, but more likely a result of IV steroids given at OSH.
   Now down trending
   - Trend WBC
   - D/C
ed steroids as it was felt that his presentation was not c/w COPD
   exacerbation.
   - If hypersensitivity pneumonitis is thought to be a possible source,
   could reinitiate steroid therapy.  Will discuss with chest radiology if
   appearance on CXR could be consistent.
   # Chronic Renal Insufficiency: Baseline creatinine of 2 per OSH records
   and currently 2.6, from 1.9 at OSH at time of transfer.  Likely due to
   poor forward flow due to hypotension (likely severe sepsis).
   - Trend BUN/Cr.
   - Renally dose meds.
   - Avoid nephrotoxins.
   - Monitor UOP.
   # Aspiration: this is likely the source of his PNA based on OSH records
   and failed limited S+S eval at OSH when on bipap.
   - Tube feeds with nutrition recs
   - Treating aspiration PNA with abx as above.
   - When extubated will need S+S eval prior to eating.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health status as follows:

The patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of hypertension, chronic renal insufficiency, anxiety, and recent admission to the hospital for gastroenteritis. He was transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) due to worsening acute hypoxic respiratory failure and pneumonia (PNA). The patient has been treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics, including vancomycin, Zosyn, and ciprofloxacin, and has been intubated and mechanically ventilated.

The patient's respiratory status has been deteriorating, with increasing oxygen requirements and decreasing lung compliance. The patient's PEEP has been decreased from 15 to 10 cmH2O, and sedation has been increased to improve oxygenation. The patient's blood pressure has been hypotensive, requiring the use of vasopressors, and his cardiac output is likely decreased.

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis, hypernatremia, and chronic renal insufficiency. His blood cultures are pending, and he has been treated with antibiotics for possible sepsis.

The patient's chest X-ray suggests tuberculosis (TB), and he is being treated with respiratory isolation and empiric treatment for TB. He is also being treated for possible fungal infection and has been referred to an infectious disease specialist for further evaluation.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is deteriorating, and he may require further interventions to improve oxygenation and lung compliance.
2. Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis and hypotension suggest possible sepsis, which may worsen his respiratory and cardiac status.
3. Renal failure: The patient's chronic renal insufficiency may worsen due to his hypotension and decreased cardiac output.
4. Infection: The patient's pneumonia and possible sepsis may lead to further complications, such as ARDS, and may require additional antibiotics and supportive care.
5. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's hypotension and decreased cardiac output may lead to further cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac failure.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's sedation and decreased cardiac output may lead to neurological complications, such as confusion or seizures.

Based on the patient's condition, I recommend the following:

1. Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics to treat possible sepsis and PNA.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
3. Treat the patient's hypotension with vasopressors and fluids as needed.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and adjust medication dosing as needed.
5. Consider further evaluation and treatment for possible TB and fungal infection.
6. Monitor the patient's neurological status closely and adjust sedation as needed.
7. Continue to provide supportive care, including nutrition and hydration, to help the patient recover from his illness.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of hypertension, chronic renal insufficiency, and anxiety, who was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with worsening acute hypoxic respiratory failure and pneumonia (PNA). 

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 400 mL, PEEP of 15 cmH2O, and FiO2 of 70%. The patient's oxygenation is compromised, and there is a concern for possible acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
2. Hypotension: The patient is receiving vasopressor support and has been weaned down to two pressors (levo and vaso). The hypotension is likely secondary to sepsis, sedation, and possible high PEEP.
3. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count has increased from 14.7 K/uL to 27.9 K/uL, which could represent progression of infection or a response to IV steroids.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level is elevated, and hyperchloremia is present. The hypernatremia has been resolved.
5. Chronic renal insufficiency: The patient's creatinine level has increased from 1.9 to 2.6, likely due to poor forward flow due to hypotension.
6. Aspiration: The patient likely aspirated during his transfer from the other hospital, which led to his PNA.
7. Fever: The patient has a temperature of 38.2°C, which may be secondary to infection.

The potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Progression of ARDS: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to worsen if not managed promptly.
2. Sepsis: The patient's hypotension and leukocytosis suggest that he may be developing sepsis.
3. Renal failure: The patient's chronic renal insufficiency may worsen if not managed effectively.
4. Aspiration pneumonia: The patient may develop further complications from his aspiration, including respiratory failure and sepsis.
5. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia may worsen if not managed effectively.
6. Fungal infection: The patient's fungal markers are pending, and there is a concern for possible fungal infection.

The plan for the patient's care includes:

1. Managing the patient's respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation and adjusting the settings as needed.
2. Treating the patient's hypotension with vasopressors and fluid expansion.
3. Managing the patient's leukocytosis with antibiotics and monitoring for signs of infection.
4. Managing the patient's hypernatremia with free water flushes.
5. Monitoring the patient's chronic renal insufficiency with serial creatinine levels and adjusting medication dosing as needed.
6. Managing the patient's aspiration pneumonia with antibiotics and monitoring for signs of improvement.
7. Monitoring the patient's fever and adjusting treatment as needed.
8. Considering a chest CT if the patient's condition stabilizes and no other diagnostic clues are present.

   # Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: Patient likely hypoxic secondary to PNA

d intracardiac shunt, responsive to

   this picture may also contribute to this.   CXR is questionable for

 sent for markers and mini-BAL

 for consideration of  fungal infection

   (levo/vaso).  Likely [**1-12**] sepsis and sedation, and possible high PEEP,

 persistent, with hyperchloremia, now resolved.

ed steroids as it was felt that his presentation was not c/w COPD

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of hypertension, chronic renal insufficiency, anxiety, and recent admission to the hospital for gastroenteritis. He was transferred to the ICU with worsening acute hypoxic respiratory failure and pneumonia (PNA). The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 400 mL, FiO2 of 70%, and PEEP of 15 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Leukocytosis (27.9 K/uL)
* Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (384 IU/L)
* Hypernatremia (156 mmol/L)
* Hyperchloremia (141 mmol/L)
* Elevated creatinine (2.6 mg/dL)
* Elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) (27 mmol/L)
* Elevated liver enzymes (ALT 39 IU/L, AST 28 IU/L)
* Low albumin (2.8 g/dL)

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Hypoxic respiratory failure
* PNA
* Chronic renal insufficiency
* Leukocytosis
* Hypernatremia
* Hyperchloremia
* Hyperlipidemia
* Chronic renal failure

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
2. Sepsis
3. Renal failure
4. Pneumonia
5. Hypotension
6. Hypercapnia
7. Hypoxia
8. Aspiration
9. Fungal infection
10. Legionella infection
11. Mycoplasma infection

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Restricting tidal volume as per ARDS protocol
* Continuing broad-spectrum antibiotics (Vanc/Zosyn/cipro)
* Monitoring for sepsis and adjusting treatment accordingly
* Trending WBC and adjusting therapy as necessary
* Renally dosing medications
* Avoiding nephrotoxins
* Monitoring UOP
* Elevating the head of bed (HOB) to prevent aspiration
* Providing tube feeds with nutrition recommendations
* Treating aspiration PNA with antibiotics
* Performing a swallowing evaluation prior to eating when extubated

The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate), and his disposition is unknown.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of hypertension, chronic renal insufficiency, anxiety, and recent admission for gastroenteritis, who was transferred to the ICU with worsening acute hypoxic respiratory failure and pneumonia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: Hypoxic respiratory failure with refractory hypoxia, likely due to aspiration pneumonia, with diffuse ground-glass opacities on CXR.
* Cardiovascular: Hypotension, likely due to sepsis, sedation, and possible high PEEP, with a baseline creatinine of 2 and currently 2.4, indicating chronic renal insufficiency.
* Hematological: Leukocytosis, likely due to IV steroids given at OSH, with a WBC count of 27.9.
* Infectious: Pneumonia, likely aspiration-related, with sputum cultures pending, and blood cultures pending.
* Nutritional: Tube feeds with nutrition recommendations, and IVF bolus PRN for low UOP.
* Renal: Renally dose meds, avoid nephrotoxins, and monitor UOP.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS)
* Sepsis
* Pneumonia
* Aspiration
* Chronic Renal Insufficiency
* Leukocytosis
* Hyperlipidemia
* Hypotension
* Respiratory failure
* Cardiovascular instability
* Infection-related complications

The plan of care includes:

* Restricted tidal volume as per ARDS protocol
* Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics with Vanc/Zosyn/cipro
* Endotracheal sputum cultures, blood cultures
* Follow-up with ID recs
* Consider mini-BAL and fungal markers
* Wean sedation as tolerated
* Volume expansion with NS as needed
* Hold lisinopril, doxazosin
* Trend WBC
* Continue solumedrol empirically
* Trend BUN/Cr.
* Renally dose meds.
* Avoid nephrotoxins.
* Monitor UOP.
* Tube feeds with nutrition recs
* Treating aspiration PNA with abx as above.
* If extubated, would need S+S eval prior to eating.
* HOB elevation, aspiration precautions.

The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate), and his disposition is unclear.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of hypertension, chronic renal insufficiency, anxiety, and recent admission for gastroenteritis. He was transferred from an outside hospital (OSH) due to worsening acute hypoxic respiratory failure and pneumonia (PNA).

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient is likely hypoxic secondary to PNA from aspiration, and there is concern for possible acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). He is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics and has had a family meeting to discuss goals of care.
2. Hypotension: The patient became acutely hypotensive overnight and was transiently dependent on three pressors. He is now weaned down to two pressors, and his hypotension is likely due to sepsis, sedation, and possible high positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP).
3. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count has increased from 14 to 27.9, which may represent progression of infection or a result of IV steroids given at OSH.
4. Chronic Renal Insufficiency: The patient's baseline creatinine is 2, and it has increased to 2.4 due to poor forward flow and hypotension.
5. Aspiration: The patient likely aspirated food or liquid, which is the source of his PNA. He is being treated with antibiotics and has a tube feeding plan in place.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's hypotension and leukocytosis suggest possible sepsis, which may lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. ARDS: The patient's hypoxic respiratory failure and diffuse ground-glass opacities on chest X-ray (CXR) raise concerns for possible ARDS, which may lead to respiratory failure and need for mechanical ventilation.
3. Chronic kidney disease progression: The patient's increasing creatinine levels and hypotension may lead to further kidney damage and progression of chronic kidney disease.
4. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's tube feeding plan may lead to nutritional deficiencies, particularly if not properly managed.
5. Infection: The patient's PNA and leukocytosis suggest possible infection, which may lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction if not properly treated.

To address these potential complications, the patient's care plan should include:

1. Close monitoring of vital signs, laboratory results, and respiratory status.
2. Aggressive treatment of sepsis and PNA with broad-spectrum antibiotics and supportive care.
3. Management of hypotension with volume expansion and pressor therapy as needed.
4. Monitoring of kidney function and adjusting medications accordingly.
5. Close follow-up with the patient's primary care physician and infectious disease specialist to ensure proper treatment and management of his condition.

   Assessment and Plan
   85yo M with h/o HTN, CRI, anxiety, and recent admission at OSH for
   gastroenteritis, who is transfered from an OSH with worsening acute
   hypoxic respiratory failure and PNA.
   .
   # Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: Patient likely hypoxic secondary to PNA
   from aspiration per OSH records, was given steroid at OSH for COPD
   exacerbation, but held as not likely the source. Given progression,
   concern exists for possible [**Doctor Last Name 11**]/ARDS.  Hypoxia was refractory to 70%
   FiO2, question if shunt, TTE r/o
d intracardiac shunt, responsive to
   80% and PEEP (usually relates to the level of sedation pt is getting)
   related to respiratory effort.  Hypercapnia is likely due to poor
   perfusion of the lung, with possible increased CO2 production in the
   peripheral tissues and dysynchrony with the vent.  Component of ARDS in
   this picture may also contribute to this.   CXR is questionable for
   infection/edema/granulomatous disease. Review of [**Month (only) 2299**] Xrays reveals
   early stages of same process, prompting initation of steroids.
   Negative for PJP, fungal markers. ID is following.
   - Family meeting today for goals of care
   - Restricted tidal volume as per ARDS protocol
   - Continue broad spectrum abx with Vanc/Zosyn/cipro for now.
   - f/u CXR for interval improvement on steroids
   - f/u cxs
   - f/u ID recs
 sent for markers and mini-BAL
   -  consider diuresis with lasix gtt given possible radiographic
   evidence of pulmonary edema
   .
   # Hypotension: patient became acutely hypotensive o/n on [**3-7**], was
   transiently dependent on 3 pressors(levo/neo/vaso) initially, now
   weaned down to 2 (levo/vaso).  Blood pressure is downtrending as of [**3-10**]
   on this regimen. Likely [**1-12**] sepsis and sedation, and possible high
   PEEP.  We expect that treating the underlying infection may improve
   this. Old CXR reviewed; showed perihilar opacities that could
   potentially represent initial lesions that have now progressed.  As
   this could potentially represent hypersensitivity pneumonitis, and
   because no infectious source has been identified, empirically restarted
   solumedrol [**3-9**] 125 mg IV x 1.
   - volume expansion with NS as needed
   - wean sedation as tolerated
   - Holding lisinopril, doxazosin.
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Pt had leukocytosis on admission to OSH of 14. This has
   bumped to 27.9 at time of transfer,  Could represent progression of
   infection/PNA, but more likely a result of IV steroids given at OSH.
   Continues to downtrend, is 11 today.
   - Trend WBC
   - continue solumedrol empirically?
   .
   # Chronic Renal Insufficiency: Baseline creatinine of 2 per OSH records
   and currently 2.4, from 1.9 at OSH at time of transfer.  Likely due to
   poor forward flow due to hypotension (likely severe sepsis).
   - Trend BUN/Cr.
   - Renally dose meds.
   - Avoid nephrotoxins.
   - Monitor UOP.
   .
   # Aspiration: this is likely the source of his PNA based on OSH records
   and failed limited S+S eval at OSH when on bipap.
   - Tube feeds with nutrition recs
   - Treating aspiration PNA with abx as above.
   - If extubated, would need S+S eval prior to eating.
   - HOB elevation, aspiration precautions.
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: Continue current regimen of pravastatin 10 mg QHS.
   .
   #  FEN: IVF bolus PRN for low UOP, replete electrolytes PRN, NPO.
   # Access: PICC
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Arterial Line - [**2112-3-6**] 01:29 PM
   PICC Line - [**2112-3-7**] 11:30 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: H2 blocker
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments: Family meeting
   Code status: DNR (do not resuscitate)
   Disposition:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 85-year-old male with a history of hypertension, chronic renal insufficiency, anxiety, and recent admission to the hospital for gastroenteritis. He was transferred to the ICU with worsening acute hypoxic respiratory failure and pneumonia (PNA).

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: He is on a pressure control vent with a FiO2 of 70% and PEEP of 15 cmH2O. His SpO2 is 97%. His ABG shows a pH of 7.28, PaO2 of 161, and PaCO2 of 57.
* Cardiovascular: He is hypotensive and requires two pressors (levo and vaso) to maintain blood pressure. His blood pressure is downtrending.
* Renal: His baseline creatinine is 2, and his current creatinine is 2.4. He has chronic renal insufficiency and is at risk for acute kidney injury due to hypotension and sepsis.
* Infectious: He has PNA and is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics (Vanc/Zosyn/cipro). He also has a history of aspiration and is at risk for aspiration pneumonia.
* Metabolic: He has hyperlipidemia and is being treated with pravastatin.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Sepsis
* Acute kidney injury
* Aspiration pneumonia
* Hypoxia
* Hypercapnia
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Pneumonia

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continuing broad-spectrum antibiotics
* Restricting tidal volume as per ARDS protocol
* Monitoring for signs of sepsis and adjusting treatment accordingly
* Treating aspiration PNA with antibiotics
* Elevation of head of bed to prevent aspiration
* Monitoring for signs of acute kidney injury and adjusting treatment accordingly
* Managing hyperlipidemia with pravastatin

The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate).
